div.p: vuAra sira rahyaṁta I hāra ṅarannira Ari rahyaṁta ri mḍaṁ, sira ta magavai bihāra I pikatan· tutuganniṁ taṇḍa,

Iṁ śaka 668 Aśujimāsa pañcādaśi śukla, pa papa Aṁ,
Aḍiri rakai panaṅkaran·, sira ta Umarpaṇākan· Ikanaṁ savaḥ haji lān· I vanuA tṅaḥ vatak· pikatan· rikanaṁ bihāra I pikatan·, luĀnikanaṁ savaḥ paṅavaitanya lambyan·
lor· ḍpa sihvā 182 paṅavaitanya lambyan· kidul· ḍpa sihvā 162 paṅalor·nya lamvyan· vaitan· ḍpa sihvā 160 paṅidul·nya lamvyan· kuluAn· ḍpa sihvā 162 viniḥ
nya tū 3
Iṁ śaka 706 cetramāsa daśami śukla, pa ka śa, vāra, Aṁḍiri rake panaraban·, tann inulahulaḥ Ikanaṁ savaḥ lān· I vanuA tṅaḥ An tama rikanaṁ bihāra I pikatan·,

Iṁ śaka 725 cetra
māsa śaṣṭi śukla, pa U śu, vāra, maṁḍiri rake varak· dyaḥ manara, sira ta Umabak· Ikanaṁ sīma pjaḥ rake varak· siraṁ lumāḥ Iṁ kelāsa,

Iṁ śaka 749 śravaṇamāsa, caturdaśi kr̥ṣṇa, vā pa śu vāra, maṁ
ḍiri dyaḥ gula, tan·n uvaḥ Ataḥ Ikanaṁ sīma rikanaṁ bihāra I pikatan·,

Iṁ śaka 750 māghamāsa dvitīya śukla, pa U Ā, vāra, Aḍiri rake garuṁ Anak· saṁ lumāḥ I tūk·, sira ta Umaluyakan· Ikanaṁ sa
vaḥ sīma Irikanaṁ bīhāra I pikatan·

svasti śakavarṣātīta 751 mārggaśīramāsa tithi caturdaśi śuklapakṣa, vu va vr̥, vāra, tatkāla śrī mahārāja rakai garuṁ Umaluyaka
n· Ikanaṁ savaḥ haji lān· I vanuA tṅaḥ sīmani bihāra I pikatan·, Ikana binabak· śrī mahārāja saṁ lumāḥ Iṁ kelāsa, patiḥ tatkāla vka pu taṅgal·, sirikan pu sūryya, pikatan pu pañculiṁ, mamava
bīhāra sa vatu humalaṁ, vruḥ ḍaṅ ācāryya devendra, Anuṁ Umilu kinon· śrī mahārāja, Umaluyakna Ikanaṁ savaḥ \red{Iṁ} vihāra I pikatan· vahuta makudur· I vka I sirikan· I palar hyaṁ, I hala
ran·, I vlahan·, I jalinan·, I paṅkur·, I tavān·, I tirip·, I lampi, I vatu humalaṁ, I pikatan·, I mamrati, I tilimpik·, I tiruAn·, I maṁhuri, patiḥ I pikatan· saṁ vanuA tṅaḥ pu culiṁ, saṁ
tuṅgal aṅin· pu ramvat·, lekan pu glam·, saṁ ra gunuṁ pu Intap·, saṁ samalagi pu talisū, ḍaṅ ācāryya paṅajyan· I pikatan· bhadracandra, patati vandāmi bhadrasūryya, vihārasvāmi saṁṅ āryya, pañcavā
ra punta mandana .

nahan· praśasti rake ga
ruṁ Ar· Uvahakan· Ikanaṁ savaḥ sīma Iṁ bihāra I pikatan·, pjaḥ rake garuṁ,
Iṁ śaka 768 phālguṇamāsa pratipāda kr̥ṣṇa, pa ka Ā, vāra, maṁḍiri rake pikatan· dyaḥ salaḍū, sira kapiṇḍuAniṁ lumabvur· Ika\red{na} sīma, pjaḥ rake pikatan·,

I śaka
777 jyeṣṭamāsa pañcami kr̥ṣṇa, ha va śa, vāra, maṁḍiri rake kayuvaṅi dyaḥ lokapāla matəhər· tan uvaḥ Ikanaṁ sima, pjaḥ rake kayuvaṅi,

Iṁ śaka 806 māghamāsa caturdaśi kr̥ṣṇa, tuṁ po bu, vāra, maṁḍiri dyaḥ tagvas·\red{,}\ tan uvaḥ Ataḥ Ikanaṁ sīma rikanaṁ bihā
ra I pikatan·, kādəḥ dyaḥ tagvas· riṁ kaḍatvan·,
Iṁ śaka 807 Aśujimāsa pañcami kr̥ṣṇa, pakṣa, pa pa bu, vāra, maṁḍiri rake panumvaṅan· dyaḥ devendra, tan uvaḥ Ataḥ Ikanaṁ sīma, kādəḥ rake panumvaṅan· Iṁ kaḍatvan·,

I śaka 808 māghamāsa, pañcami kr̥ṣṇa, vā po bu,
vāra, maṁḍiri rake gurunbaṅi dyaḥ bhadra, miṅgat· rake gurunbaṅi, Irikanaṁ samaṅkanātaḥ phalguṇnamāsa, dvitīya kr̥ṣṇa, pakṣa, Anāyaka Ikanaṁ rāt· rikaṁ kāla,

Iṁ śaka 816 mārggāśīramāsa pañcami kr̥ṣṇa, tuṁ pa br̥, vāra, maṁḍiri rake vuṅkal· humalaṁ dyaḥ jbaṁ, tamolaḥ
Ātaḥ Ikanaṁ savaḥ I vanua tṅa I śrī mahārāja, pinakakmitannira I luA, tan uvaḥ rikanaṁ bihāra I pikatan·, pjaḥ rake vuṅkal· humalaṁ,

Iṁ śaka 820 jyeṣṭamāsa tithi pratipāda kr̥ṣṇa, tu po bu, vāra Irikār pāṁḍiri śrī mahārāja rake vatukura dyaḥ balituṁ śrī
Iśvarakeśavotsavatuṅga rudramūrti, mahāmantrīnira rakryān· I hino śrī dakṣottama bāhubajra pratipakṣakṣāya viṣṇumūrtti,

Iṁ śaka 826 mārggasīramāsa tithi dvitīya śuklapakṣa, vu U so, vāra, Irikān pisor· Ājñanira kumonakan· saṁ hyaṁ
dharmmā bihāra I java kabaiḥ svatantrā Umāryya kaḍaṇḍān·,

I śaka 827 kārtikamāsa tithi caturdaśi śukla, pakṣa, pa po Aṁ, vāra, Umuṅgaḥ śrī mahārāja riṁ kaḍatvan· saṅkā ri nyū gaḍiṁ, rikanaṁ kulam· Irikān· pamatipī bhaṭāra svāmi mahulun· I lekan·
I rakryān· mahāmantrī I hino śrī dakṣottama bāhujrapratipakṣakṣaya, kumonnakan· Ikanaṁ savaḥ sima saṁ hyaṁ bihāra I pikatan· Uvahakna, yathānyan· mapagəha paluṅguḥ śrī mahārāja Iṁ kaḍatvan·,

Iṁ śaka 830 Aśujimāsa padmanābha de
vatā, tithi daśami śuklapakṣa, tuṁ pa vr̥, vāra, karmmeśa deva, vālava karaṇa, Uttarāṣāḍhanakṣatra, viśva deva, śukla yoga kārmuka lagna, yama deśa, Irikā divasanikanaṁ savaḥ sīma I pikatan·n inuvahakan· I saṁ hyaṁ vihāra I pikatan·,

Anuṁ kinon· śrī mahārāja muAṁ rakryān mahāmantrī Umuvaha
kna Ikanaṁ savaḥ I vihāra I pikatan· rakryān· limvayan dyaḥ guṇam muAṁ ḍaṅ ācāryya Iṁ tūk· dhāneśvara Umyāpārā kasusukananikanaṁ vuṅkal·, maṅasəAkan· ḍaṅ· saṁgha I pikatan· pagəḥ-pagəḥ I śrī mahārāja vḍihan· piliḥ magə:ṁ yu 1 jaro yu 1 pirak· dhā 8 kinonakan· ra
kryān· kabaiḥ varahan· An· maṅkanā parṇnahanikanaṁ sava haji lān· I vanuA tṅaḥ, rakryān· I halu pu vīravikrama, rakryān· sirikan pu variga samaravikranta, vka pu kutak· pu bhāsvara, tiruAn· saṁ śivāstra, halaran· pu kivi, palar hyaṁ pu pu
ñjaṁ, jalinan· pu maṅusir·, maṁhuri pu cakra, paṅkur· pu rañjan·, tavān pu pañjaluAn·, tirip· pu viṣṇu, saṁ parujar· Iṁ kabalān· I hino kaṇḍamuhi pu tuṁṅgaṁ, citralekha vuṅkal· varaṇi pu manəsər·, parujar· I halu visaga pu damodara, I siri
kan· hujuṁ galuḥ pu Ayuddhā, citralekha dharmmāsinta, I vka viridiḥ pu ḍaṇu, citralekha halaṁ manuk· ḍapunta vuru tuk·, I tiruAn· sumuḍan· ḍapunta bhāsura, parujar· I halaran· savi manuk· pu dharmma, I palar· hyaṁ rumakat· pu baka, I jalinan·
ravaryyaṁ saṁ mudgalyāna, I maṁhuri raruI, I paṅkur dədəlan·, I tavān· rāluk·, I tirip· paḍaṁ, kapuA sira kabaiḥ makobhaya Ikanaṁ pasək pasək· kaharan· maparaha I sira, kunaṁ samgat· mamrata pūttara, samgat tilimpik· pu sudar·, Ina
səAn· pagə-pagəḥ vḍihan· kalyāga yu 1 pirak· dhā 4 sovaṁ, saṁ mamuAt· Ujar· Iṁ kasiṅgahan· turuhan· saṁ panagar·, citralekha kr̥p· pu jayamatiḥ, I tilimpik· vka-vka pu babru, citralekha pati lamman· vineḥ pagə-pagəḥ vḍihan· yu 1 pi
rak· dhā 1 sovaṁ, parujar· saṁ māna\red{k·} Iṁ kasiṅgahan· I paṅkur piṅkaṅan·, I tavān· likuAn·, I tirip· Air bavu, vineḥ pagə-pagəḥ vḍihan· ragi yu 1 pirak· mā 8 sovaṁ, pihujuṁni parujar· saṁ mānak· I paṅkur· luA, I tavān· sukun·, I tirip· pana
vuṅan·, vineḥ pagə-pagəḥ vḍihan· yu 1 pirak· mā 6 sovaṁ, vahuta haji Iṁ kasiṅgahan·, I mamrati priḥ pu godhara, I tilimpik· jukut er pu jaṅga, vineḥ pagə-pagəḥ vḍihan· yu 1 pirak· dhā 1 sovaṁ, saṁ raluA pu salaru vineḥ vḍihan·
yu 1 pirak· dhā 2 baṇigrāma I luA maṅabaihi pirak· dhā 3 saṁ kabayan· I mamrāti maṅabehi pirak· dhā 3 saṁ paṅuraṁ Iṁ kapartayān· rake vakaḥ pu khaṭvāṅga, turuhan· saṁ panagar·, saṁ kasugihan· pu prājña, prasan· saṁ śikhā, ma
lañjaṁ saṁ Aghora, roṅguy· pu kutur·, lva Iṁ kamaṇikan· saṁ nīla muAṁ saṁ drampuAs·, ḍapunta garalek·, ḍapunta Anidhana, maṅabaiḥhi pirak· dhā 5 sira ri Ayam· təAs·, lumaku manusuk· vineḥ pirak· dhā 3 hop· vḍihan·
hop· paṅaṅkat·, sira I makudur· lumaku manusuk· vineḥ pirak· dhā 3 hop· vḍihan·, hopaṅaṅkat·, kabayan· ri Ayam· təAs· 2 mira-miraḥ pu rayuṁ, halaran· pu dhanada, vineḥ pagə-pagəḥ pirak· dhā 1 mā 8 sovaṁ, ka
bayan· I makudur· 2 pataL̥san· pu vīryya, vavahan· pu danta, vineḥ pagə-pagəḥ pirak· dhā 1 mā 8 sovaṁ . . .

piṅhe I pagar vsi si maṅaruḥ ramani sadhaṇa, piṅhai I pikatan· Asam pañjaṁ si syāmā ramani bikrāmī, muva[ḥ]
piṅhai I pikatan·, vijyāṅin· si kusuma ramani lābha, muvaḥ piṅhai I pikatan· guṇuṁ si mriḥ ramaṇni Astiti, muvaḥ piṅhai I pikatan· Asam pañjaṁ, si balava, muvaḥ piṅhai I pikatan· lekan·, si jalū ramani ka
piṅhai I tira siṅgaṁ si rasuk·, muAṁ si dhavala ramani kesara, kapuA vineḥ vḍihan· R̥ṅga yu 1 mās· mā 1 sovaṁ-sovaṁ, vanuA tṅaḥ prāṇa 3 si maṅhuri ramani kanaka, si Ananta ramani kaṇṭara, muAṁ si liṅga ramani Cḍi
raṁ saṁ ra lampi, si balu ramani L̥bā, kapuA vinaiḥ vḍihan· R̥ṅga yu 1 mās· mā 1 sovaṁ-sovaṁ, vahuta I pagar vsi si kaṇḍara ramani prasena, vahuta I pikatan· kupaṁ, si tovoḥ ramani Arā, vahuta I tira
ramani Asiḥ, kapuA vineḥ vḍihan R̥ṁga yu 1 mās· mā 1 sovaṁ-sovaṁ, piluṅgaḥnya, si man·dyus· ramani veda, vineḥ mās· mā 1 muvaḥ pihai I pikatan· Anuṁ lampuran· si gayatrī muAṁ si vanuA
n·

lampuran· Anak·, kapuA vinaiḥ mās· ku 2 sovaṁ-sovaṁ, rāma māgman· I vanuA tṅaḥ gusti prāṇa 2 si sodai ramani basu, muAṁ si kusalā ramani ratha, vinkas· prāṇa 2 si vaṅun· ramani sarini, muAṁ si ḍakat· ramani la
ṅgaṇa, kalima prāṇa 2 si govana ramani Ujjhā, muAṁ si biṣātha ramani vailā, huler· prāṇa 2 si kalula ramani prayanta, muAṁ si candra ramani gḍā, parujar· praṇa 2 si kətoḥ ramani muditā, muAṁ si pundut· ramani laṇḍuṁ, ka
puA vinaiḥ vḍihan· R̥ṅga yu 1 mās· mā 1 sovaṁ-sovaṁ, hulu kuvu si tañjuṅan· ramani bacuṁ, muAṁ si lucchira vineḥ mās· ku 1 sovaṁ-sovaṁ, rāma maratā Anuṁ kabayan· si haḍa ramani bhara, muAṁ si glar· ramani skar·, si vuliran·
ramani rathi, si Aṁgira ramani bisuddhi, si L̥viḥ ramani kaR̥ṅəAn, si julay· ramani sabda, si yukti ramani bhoga, si vaduĀ ramani sukhamī, si goḍog· ramani suddhī, si mahi ramani mahendrī, si vaR̥g· ramani paṇḍaṁ, si tuli ramani ba
sī, kapuA vinaiḥ mas· mā 1 sovaṁ-sovaṁ, rāma tpi siriṁ, I vijyāṅin· si risi ramani basu, si piṅul· ramani buntar·, vinaiḥ mas· mā 1 sovaṁ-sovaṁ, gusti I tira I tumapal· si bharaṇa ramani kiṭak·, kalima si caṇṭuṁ ramani
carā, vinaiḥ mas· mā 2 sovaṁ-sovaṁ, tuha vəR̥ḥ praṇa 2 si kaṭal· ramani gaṇḍal·, muAṁ si bloṇḍo ramani budanta, vinaiḥ mas· mā 1 sovaṁ-sovaṁ, gusti I kuluva sy āṁs\red{ə:}, vinkas· si grihīta, vinkas· I panuṅgalan· si sojara,
kalima si mara ramani Atis·, kapuA vinaiḥ vḍihan· R̥ṅga yu 1 sovaṁ-sovaṁ, vinkas· I layaṅanak· si baskara ramani devī, vinaiḥ mas· mā 1 kalima I hulu vanuA si ruAṁ galuḥ ramani vaṅi, vinkas· si vujil·, kapuA vinaiḥ vḍiha
n· R̥ṅga yu 1 mas· mā 1 sovaṁ-sovaṁ, rāma maratā si kalula ramani yukti, vinaiḥ mas· mā 1 Anuṁ maṁlivat· rāma I samalagi pun·punan· bhaṭāra I pikatan· vinkas· si kali ramani nita, kalima si paṅalaman·, gusti si kaca ramani
radhinī, marhyaṁ si supha ramani basi, parujar· si sutə ramani vidyā, variga si vaṅun· vineḥ mas· mā 1 kinabaiḥhanya, Anuṁ mavay· Irikāṁ kāla si hriṁ ramani cakra, hulu vras· si Ama, ramani cele, Anag vanuA I luA I kabikvan· vi
naiḥ vḍihan· R̥ṅga yu 1 mā 1 AR̥ggaṁ rikaṁ kāla si kesava ramani agam· Anag vanuA I titiḥ vatak· pikatan· vinaiḥ vḍihan· R̥ṅga hlai 1 mas· ku 2 Abr̥kuk· si gḍil· ramani mundil·, Anag vanuA I varuk·, vineḥ mas· ku 2
Avayaṁ Irikaṁ kāla si kliṁ ramani sḍaṁ, Anag vanuA I vanuA tṅaḥ, vinaiḥ vḍihan· hlai 1 mas· ku 2 Atapukan· si rasuk· Anag vanuA I hinor· vinaiḥ mas· ku 3 muvaḥ tapukan· praṇa 2 vineḥ mas· mā 1 kinālihanya, tari
mvanya praṇa 6 vinaiḥ mas· ku 1 sovaṁ-sovaṁ . . .

maṅadiṣṭaṇa vuṅkal· 2 ḍaṅ upādhyāya I vraṁ candradeva, muAṁ ḍaṅ ācāryya paṅajyan· I sukun· sudanta, kapuA sira vineḥ pirak· mā 6 sovaṁ-sovaṁ, maṅaji santi 2 ḍaṅ ācāryya
I kavuṁ manek· sudanta, muAṁ ḍaṅ ācāryya I tiḍaluAṁ bhadraśena, maṅajī bantan· 2 ḍaṅ ācāryya I vraṁ ḍaṅ ācāryya tatha, muAṁ ḍaṅ acāryya I Air hijo vetan· padmaśena, kapuA sira vineḥ pirak· mā 6 sovaṁ-sovaṁ ḍaṅ ācā
ryya paṅajyan· I pikatan· paṇḍara, vineḥ sira pirak· mā 8 ḍaṅ ācāryya Iṁ air· hijo kuluAn· sudanta, vineḥ pirak· mā 6 patati I pikatan· ḍapunta devendra, patati Iṁ Air hijo vetan· dhanendra, patati Iṁ Air hijo kuluAn·
ḍapunta samahita, patati I guluṁ ḍapunta Akṣa, kapuA vineḥ pirak· mā 2 sovaṁ-sovaṁ, Ayam· təAs· milu manusuk· sīma si bilāsa ramani tatha, Anag vanuA I paṅsur·, vatak· Ayam· təAs· vineḥ vḍihan· R̥ṅga yu 1
mas· mā 6 makudur· maṅuyup·, si dayanna Anag vanuA I kahaṅatan·, vatak· hamməAs·, vineḥ vḍihan· R̥ṅga yu 1 mā 2 makudur tan· paṅuyup si jaṅgi ramani vulakan· Anag vanuA I vaduṁ poḥ vatak· paṅkur· poḥ vi
naiḥ vḍihan· R̥ṅga yu 1 mā 2 .

yāpuAn· hana vuAṁ Umulahulaḥ \red{Ike}ṁ savaḥ sīma punya śrī mahārāja muAṁ rakryān· mahāmantrī I bhaṭāra I pikatan· bhaṭāra svāmi mahulun· I lekan· Umupadr̥vā ya syūha avak·nya
bhraṣṭā pomahumaḥnya Anak·nya vkanya Umaṅguha saṁsāra savukaniṁṅ uE dumliṁ pjaḥ ya dlāha pañca mahāpātaka tmūnyū .
There once was a prince of Hāra, younger brother of the prince of Mḍaṅ. He founded the monastery at Pikatan tutuganniṁ taṇḍa.

On Śaka 668, month Aśuji, fifteenth, waxing, Paniruan (of the 6-day week), Pahiṅ (of the 5-day week), Tuesday, did Rakai Panaṅkaran mount the throne. He endowed the king's lān wet rice-field in Vanua Tṅah, domain of Pikatan, to the monastery at Pikatan. The extent of the wet rice-field from east to west on the north side is 182 ḍpa sihvā; from east to west on the south side it is 162 ḍpa sihvā; from north to south on the east side it is 160 ḍpa sihvā; from south to north on the west side it is 162 ḍpa sihvā. Its seed is 3 tū.

On Śaka 706, month Cetra, tenth, waxing, Paniruan, Kaliwuan, Saturday, did Rakai Panaraban mount the throne. The [status of the] lān wet rice-field in Vanua Tṅah was not changed: it was under the authority of the monastery at Pikatan.

On Śaka 725, month Cetra, sixth, waxing, Paniruan, Umanis, Friday, did Rakai Varak Dyaḥ Manara mount the throne. He annulled/changed the endowment ([re]moved the boundary markers). Rakai Warak, he who came to rest at Kelāsa, died.
On Śaka 749, month Śravaṇa, fourteenth, waning, Vās, Pahing, Friday, did Dyaḥ Varak mount the throne. The [status of the] endowment to the monastery at Pikatan did not change further.

On Śaka 750, month Māgha, second, waxing, Paniruan, Umanis, Sunday, did Rakai Garuṅ, child of him who rests at Tūk, mount the throne. He restored the wet rice-field as endowment to the monastery at Pikatan.

Hail! Elapsed Śaka year 751, the fourteenth day of the month Mārgaśira, waxing fortnight, Vurukuṅ, Vagai, Thursday. At that time did his majesty Rakai Garuṅ restore the king's lān wet rice-field in Vanua Tṅah, as endowment of the monastery at Pikatan, which has been discontinued by his majesty who rests at Kelāsa. The minister at that time in Vka was Pu Taṅgal; the [minister in] Sirikan was Pu Sūrya; the [minister in] Pikatan was Pu Pañculiṅ. Saṅ Vatu Humalaṅ led the monastery. Ḍaṅ Ācārya Devendra had knowledge [of the matter]. Those who \red{also} received the order from his majesty to restore the wet rice-field to the monastery at Pikatan were the Vahuta Makudurs at Vka, Sirikan, Palar Hyaṅ, Halaran, Vlahan, Dalinan, Paṅkur, Tavān, Tirip, Lampi, Vatu Humalaṅ, Pikatan, Mamrati, Tilimpik, Tiruan, Maṅhuri; the minister of Pikatan from Vanua Tṅah, Pu Culiṅ; from Tuṅgal Aṅin, Pu Ramvat; from Lekan, Pu Glam; from Ra Gunuṅ, Pu Intap; from Samalagi, Pu Talisū; Ḍaṅ Ācārya for scriptural study at Pikatan, Bhadracandra; the Patati Vandāmi, Bhadrasūrya; abbot Saṅ Ārya; Pañcavāra Punta Mandana.

I. In the year [denoted by] the (1) moon, the (5) senses and the (7) teachers (i.e.\ in śaka 751), in the month of Mārga(śira), on the fourth and in the waxing fortnight, on Vurukuṁ (of the 6-day week), Mitra (= Vagai, a day of the 5-day week) and on Thursday (jīvaka;
II. with the one name Candrabhadra as Professor, with Bhadrasūrya as Partati (?), with Ārya as \red{owner of the monastery} and with Mandana as Pañcavāra;
III. but with Devendra, praised by the praiseworthy, perfect in virtues such as meditation, blessed, honored by the king, as Rector;
IV. the one called Culiṅ in Center Town (= Vanua Tṅah); and Ramvat from Tuṅgal Aṅin; the one called Glam from/as Lekan; and Intap \red{from} Ra Gunuṅ;
V. and Talisū from Samalagi --- these five (being) the principal towns, which are all under injunction not to be given (?) ---; with these as participants:
VI. the minister of Vka was Taṅgal; the [minister of] Sirikan was called Sūrya; and the cuirass-bearer, the sword (bearer?) is called Kudur;
VII. the Pikatan is called Pañculiṅ; the abbot was a hero from Humalaṅ Stone, known by the name of Gnaṅ;
VIII. and the Palar Hyaṅ, the Halaran, the Vlahan, the Dalinan, the Paṅkur, the Tavān, the Tirip, the Tilimpik, the Lampi, the Mamrati,
IX. the Tiruan, the Maṅhuri, and the Vahuta Makudur. They were all assigned the task of protecting the rice-field by order of Bhānubhadra.
X. For the rice-field that is at Center Town, under the monastery whose name is that of a bird, was previously donated, with proper ado, by King Panaṅkara.
XI. It was taken back by the passionate King Varak called Manāra, whose monastery-governors were \red{driven away (?)} by order of Garuṅ.
Such was the decree of Rake Garuṅ with regard to how he altered the status of that \red{wet rice-field whose status was that of endowment} of the monastery at Pikatan. Rake Garuṅ died.
On Śaka 768, month Phālguṇa, first, waning, Paniruan, Kaliwon, Sunday, did Rake Pikatan Dyaḥ Salaḍū mount the throne. He was the second who dissolved that endowment. Rake Pikatan died.
On Śaka 777, month Jyeṣṭha, fifth, waning, Haryaṅ, Wage, Saturday, did Rake Kayuvaṅi Dyaḥ Lokapāla mount the throne. Thereupon the status of that endowment did not change. Rake Kayuvaṅi died.

On Śaka 806, month Māgha, fourteenth, waning, Tuṅlai, Pon, Wednesday, did Dyaḥ Tagvas mount the throne. The status of that endowment of the monastery of Pikatan did not change either. Dyaḥ Tagvas was ousted from the \red{palace}.

On Śaka 807, month Aśvajit, fifth, waning fortnight, Paniruan, Pahiṅ, Wednesday, did Rake Panumwaṅan Dyaḥ Devendra mount the throne. The status of that endowment did not change either. Rake Panumwaṅan was ousted from the \red{palace}.

On Śaka 808, month Māgha, fifth, waning fortnight, Vās, Pon, Wednesday, did Rake Gurunbaṅi Dyaḥ Bhadra mount the throne. Rake Gurunbaṅi fled that very same [year] on month Phālguṇa, second, waning fortnight. The people were leaderless at the time.

On Śaka 816, month Mārgaśīrṣa, fifth, waning, Tuṅlai, Pahiṅ, Thursday, did Rake Vuṅkal Humalaṅ Dyaḥ Jbaṅ mount the throne. That wet rice-field in Vanua Tṅah of his majesty did not undergo any changes. It was kept carefully by him, in its (full) extent. There was no change with regard to the monastery at Pikatan. Rake Vuṅkal Humalaṅ died.

On Śaka 820, month Jyeṣṭha, first day, waning, Tuṅlai, Pon, Wednesday: then did his majesty Rake Vatukura Dyaḥ Balituṅ Śrī Īśvarakeśavotsavatuṅga Rudramūrti mount the throne. His chief minister was Rakryān i Hino Śrī Dakṣottama Bāhuvajrapratipakṣakṣaya Viṣṇumūrti.

On Śaka 826, month Mārgaśīrṣa, second day of the waxing fortnight, Vurukuṅ, Umanis, Monday: then did his decree come down, issuing an order with regard to the sacred monastic foundations on all of Java that they be fiscally exempt and cease to be fined.

On Śaka 827, month Kārttika, fourteenth day of the waxing fortnight, Panirwan, Pon, Tuesday, did his majesty ascend to the \red{palace}, coming from Nyū Gaḍiṅ. At night, when he pamatipī the Lord Master Almighty of/at Lekan\ to the Rakryān chief minister at Hino Śrī Dakṣottama Bāhuvajrapratipakṣakṣaya, he ordered with regard to the wet rice-field, \red{whose status was that of an endowment} of the Lord of the monastery at Pikatan that its status be altered, so that his majesty's position in the palace would be irrevocable.

\red{On Śaka 830, month Aśvajit, deity Padmanābha, tenth day of the waxing fortnight, Tuṅlai, Pahiṅ, Thursday, god Karmeśa, karaṇa Vālava, lunar mansion Uttarāṣāḍha, god Viśva, conjunction Śukla, Sagittarius in the ascendant, \red{region (?) Yama}.} That was the day that the status of the wet rice-field endowment at Pikatan was altered in favor of the Lord of the monastery at Pikatan.

Those ordered by his majesty and Rakryān chief minister to alter the status of that wet rice-field of the monastery at Pikatan [were] Rakryān Limvayan Dyah Guṇam and the master of Tūk (called) Dhaneśvara, (and) to take of the planting of the stones.
The order of Pikatan offered to the king confirmatory gifts (pagəh-pagəh): 1 yugala of very choice vəḍihan cloth; 1 yugala of jaro cloth; 8 dhāraṇa of silver.

An order was given for all the Rakryāns to be informed that the situation of the king's lān wet rice field at Vanua Tṅah would be thus: Rakryān i Halu Pu Vīravikrama; Rakryān Sirikan Pu Variga Samaravikrānta; the [Rakryāns] Vka Pu Kutak [and] Pu Bhāsvara; the Tiruan Saṅ Śivāstra; the Halaran Pu Kivi; the Palar Hyaṅ Pu Puñjaṅ; the Jalinan Pu Maṅusir; the Maṅhuri Pu Cakra; the Paṅkur Pu Rañjaṅ; the Tavān Pu Pañjaluan; the Tirip Pu Viṣṇu; the spokesman of the military of Hino, the Kaṇḍamuhi Pu Tuṅgaṅ; the calligrapher of Vuṅkal Varaṇi\ Pu Manəsər; the spokesmen of Halu, the Visaga Pu Dāmodara; of Sirikan of Hujuṅ Galuh, Pu Ayuddhā; the calligrapher of Dharmasinta; [the spokesman] of Vka Viridih Pu Ḍaṇu; the calligrapher of Halaṅ Manuk Ḍapunta Vuru Tuk; [the spokesman] of Tiruan Sumuḍan, Ḍapunta Bhāsura; the spokesman of Halaran, [function] Savi Manuk, [named] Pu Dharma; [spokesman] of Palar Hyaṅ, [function] Rumakat, [named] Pu Baka;[spokesman] of Jalinan, [function] Ravaryaṁ, [named] Saṅ Mudgalyāna;[spokesman] of Maṅhuri, [function] Rarui;[spokesman] of Paṅour, [function] Dədəlan;[spokesman] of Tavān, [function] Raluk;[spokesman] of Tirip, [function] Paḍaṅ; all of them agreed for those gifts (pasək-pasək) to be considered as credited to them.
As for the Samgat Mamrati, Pu Uttara; the Samgat Tilimpik, Pu Sudar were offered confirmatory gifts (pagəh-pagəh): 1 yugala of kalyāga cloth; 4 dhāraṇa of silver per person.

The spokesmen of Kasiṅgahan, Turuhan, Saṅ Panagar, the calligraphers Krəp, [named] Pu Jayamatiḥ; of Tilimpik, the sons of Pu Babru; [and] the calligrapher of Pati Lamman were given confirmatory gifts (pagəh-pagəh): 1 yugala of vəḍihan cloth; 1 dhāraṇa of silver per person.

The spokesman of the Saṅ Mānak at Kasiṅgahan; [spokesman] of Paṅkur, Piṅkaṅan; of Tavān, Likuan; of Tirip, Air Bavu: [they] were given confirmatory gifts (pagəh-pagəh): 1 yugala of ragi cloth; 8 māṣa of silver per person.

The assistant (?) of the spokesman with children of Paṅkur, Lua; of Tavān, Sukun; of Tirip, Panawuṅan: [they] were given confirmatory gifts (pagəh-pagəh): 1 yugala of vəḍihan cloth; 6 māṣa of silver per person.

The king's Wahuta at Kasiṅgahan; at Mamrati Prih, [named] Pu Godhara; at Tilimpik, [function] Jukut Er, [named] Pu Jaṅga: [they] were given confirmatory gifts (pagəh-pagəh): 1 yugala of vəḍihan cloth; 1 dhāraṇa of silver per person.
Saṅ Ralua Pu Salaru was given given confirmatory gifts (pagəh-pagəh): 1 yugala of vəḍihan cloth; 2 dhāraṇa of silver per person.
The community of traders of Lua all together had 3 skt{dhāraṇa} of silver. The Kabayans of Mamrāti all together had 3 dhāraṇa of silver.

The Paṅuraṅs of the Kapartayān: Rake Vakah, Pu Khaṭvāṅga; the Turuhan (called) Panagar; the Kasugihan, Pu Prājña; the Prasan (called) Śikhā; the Malañjaṅ (called Aghora); the Roṅguy, Pu Kutur; the Lwas of Kamaṇikan (called) Nīla and Drampuas; Ḍapunta Garalek; Ḍapunta Anidhana. All together had 5 dhāraṇa of silver.

Those at Ayam Tĕas departing to demarcate (the land) were given 3 dhāraṇa of silver; additionally cloth; additionally supplies. Those at Makudur departing to demarcate (the land) were given 3 dhāraṇa of silver; additionally cloth; additionally supplies. The 2 Kabayans of Ayam TəAs, viz. the Mirah-mirah, Pu Rayuṅ [and] the Halaran, Pu Dhanada were given confirmatory gifts (at the rate of) 1 dhāraṇa [and] 8 māṣa of silver each. The 2 Kabayans of Makudur, viz. the Pataləsan, Pu Vīrya; the Vavahan, Pu Danta were given confirmatory gifts (at the rate of) 1 dhāraṇa [and] 8 māṣa of silver each.

The Piṅhai of Pagar Vsi (called) Maṅaruh, father of Sadhaṇa; the Piṅhai of Pikatan Asam Pañjaṅ (called) Syāmā, father of Bikrāmī; and the Piṅhai of Pikatan Vijyāṅin (called) Kusuma, father of Lābha; and the Piṅhai of Pikatan Gunuṅ (called) Mrih, father of Astiti; and the Piṅhai of Asam Pañjaṅ (called) Balava; and the Piṅhai of Lekan (called) Jalū, father of Ka -- --; and the Piṅhai of Tira Siṅgaṅ (called) Rasuk; and Dhavala, father of Kesara; all of them were given 1 yugala of colored cloth, 1 māṣa of gold per person.

[\red{The Piṅhai}]s of Vanua Tṅah, three individuals: Maṅhuri, father of Kanaka; Ananta, father of Ka\red{ṇṭ}ara; and Liṅga, rather of ...; ... raṅ, the Ra Lampi; Balu, father of Ləbā; all of them were given 1 yugala of colored cloth, 1 māṣa of gold per person.

The Vahuta of Pagar Vsi, (called) Ka\red{ṇḍ}are, father Prasena; the Vahuta of Pikatan Kupaṅ (called) Tovoh, father of Arā; the Vahuta of Tira ..., father of Asih; all of them were given 1 yugala of colored cloth, 1 māṣa of gold per person.

Its Piluṅgah was Mandyus, father of Veda; he was given 1 māṣa of gold. And the Piṅhai of Pikatan Anuṁ (was) the singer Gāyatrī, and the Vanua ... singer children; all of them were given 2 kupaṅ of gold per person.

The māgman headmen of Vanua Tṅah: 2 Gustis, (namely) Sodai, father of Basu and Kusalā, \red{father} of Ratha; 2 Vinkas, (namely) Vaṅun, father of Sarini and Ḍakat, father of Laṅghana; 2 Kalimas, (namely) Govana, father of Ujjhā and Biṣātha, father of Vailā; 2 Hulers, (namely) Kalula, father of Prayanta and Candra, father of Gḍā; 2 Parujars, (namely) Kĕtoh, father of Muditā and Pundut, father of Laṇḍuṅ; all of them were given 1 yugala of colored cloth, 1 māṣa of gold per person.
The (two) Hulu Kuvus (named) Tañjuṅan, father of Bacuṅ; and (the one named) Lucchira were given 1 kupaṅ of gold per person.

The Maratā headmen (who served as) kabayan: Haḍa, father of Bhara and Gəlar, father of Səkar; Vuliran, father of Rathi; Aṅgira, father of Viśuddhi; Ləvih, father of Karəṅəan; Julay, father of Śabda; Yukti, father of Bhoga; Vaduā, father of Sukhamī; Goḍog, father of Suddhī; Mahi, father of Mahendrī; Varəg, father of Paṇḍaṅ; Tuli, father of Basī – all of them were given 1 māṣa of gold per person.
The neighbouring headmen of Vijyāṅin: Risi, father of Basu; Piṅul, father of Buntar --- [they] were given 1 māṣa of gold per person.
The Gusti of the \red{shore} of Tumapal (named) Bharaṇa, father of Kiṭak; the Kalima (named) Caṇṭuṅ, father of Carā --- [they] were given 2 māṣa of gold each.
The (ones serving as) Tuha Vərəh, 2 persons: Kaṭal, father of Gaṇḍal; and Bloṇḍo, father of Budanta --- [they] were give 1 māṣa of gold each.

The Gusti of Kuluva (named) Aṅsə; the Vinkas (named) Gr̥hīta; the Vinkas of Panuṅgalan (named) Sojara; the Kalima (named) Mara, father of Atis --- all of them were given 1 yugala of coloured cloth per person.
The Vinkas at Layaṅanak (named) Bhāskara, father of Devī, was given 1 māṣa of gold.
The Kalima of Hulu Vanua (named) Ruaṅ Galuh, father of Vaṅi; the Vinkas (named) Vujil: they were given 1 yugala of colored cloth each.
The Maratā headman (named) Kalula, father of Yukti was given 1 māṣa of gold.

The \red{travellers/visitors}, (namely) the /headmen of Samalagi, estate of the Lord of Pikatan: the Vinkas (named) Kali, father of Nita; the Kalima (named) Paṅalaman; the Gusti (named) Kaca, father of Radhinī; the Marhyaṅ (named) Supha, father of Basi; the spokesperson (named) Sutə, father of Vidyā; the Variga (named) Vaṅun --- all together were given 1 māṣa of gold.

Those who mavuy/mavay gave water at that time: Hriṅ, father of Cakra; the Hulu Wras (named) Ama, father of Cele, native(s) of \red{Lua at the monastery/Lua [and] of the monastery} --- they were given 1 yugala of colored cloth [and] 1 māṣa [of gold].
[The one who] played the rəgaṅ at that time: Keśava, father of Agam, native of Titih, domain of Pikatan, was given 1 sheet of coloured cloth [and] 2 kupaṅ of gold.
[The one who] played brəkuk: Gḍil, father of Mundil, native of Varuk, was given 2 kupaṅ of gold.
[The one who] performed wayang at that time: Kliṅ, father of Sḍaṅ, native of Vanua Tṅah, was given 1 sheet of cloth [and] 2 kupaṅ of gold.
[The one who] performed tapuk: Rasuk, native of Hinor, was given 3 kupaṅ of gold; also 2 tapuk players were given 1 māṣa of gold to share. His 6 tarimba [players] were given 1 kupaṅ per person.

The 2 who caused [the deity] to enter into the stone\red{s}: the teacher (upādhyāya) of Vraṅ (named) Candradeva and the master (ācārya) of recitation at Sukun (named) Sudānta. They were given 6 māṣa of silver each. The 2 who recited/performed śānti: the master of Kavuṅ Manek (named) Sudānta and the master of Tiḍaluaṅ (named) Bhadrasena; the 2 who performed offering (bantan): the (aforementioned) master of Vraṅ [and] the master (named) Tatha and the master of Air Hijo East (named) Padmasena. They were given 6 māṣa of silver per person. The master of recitation at Pikatan (named) Paṇḍara was given 8 māṣa of silver; the master of Air Hijo West (named) Sudānta was given 6 māṣa of silver. The patati of Pikatan (named) Ḍapunta Devendra; the patati of Air Hijo East (named) Dhanendra; the patati of Air Hijo West (named) Ḍapunta Samāhita; the patati of Guluṅ (named) Ḍapunta Akṣa --- they were given 2 māṣa of silver per person.

The (one who served as) Ayam Təas joining the demarcation of the endowment: Bilāsa, father of Tatha, native of Paṅsur, domain of Ayam Təas, was given 1 yugala of coloured cloth [and] 6 māṣa of gold. The Makudur who did the sucking (named) Dayanna, native of Kahaṅatan, domain of Hamməas, was given 1 yugala of coloured cloth [and] 2 māṣa [of gold]. The Makudur who did not perform uyup (named) Jaṅgi, father of Vulakan, native of Vaduṅ Poh, domain of Paṅkur Poh, was given 1 yugala of coloured cloth [and] 1 māṣa [of gold]

If there is anyone who changes the status of the rice-field of the endowment which is the meritorious work of his Majesty with the Rakryān chief minister \red{in favor of the Lord of Pikatan, Lord Master Almighty of/at Lekan}\, he will run into disaster; he will himself be ruined; his residence, his children and descendants will be destroyed; he will meet with misery; at the break of dawn he dies fully conscious; soon he will experience the [consequences of the] five cardinal sins.
